Machine Learning.question: What is the purpose of a cost function in machine learning?
options: A) To measure the performance of a model
Machine Learning.answer: A) To measure the performance of a model

Machine Learning.question: Which of the following is a supervised learning algorithm?
In which scenario is overfitting likely to occur?
Which of the following algorithms is used for classification tasks?
What is a hyperparameter in machine learning?
options: A) A parameter that is learned during training
B) A parameter that is set before the training starts
C) A parameter that adjusts dynamically during training
D) A parameter that is only used in deep learning
Machine Learning.answer: B) A parameter that is set before the training starts

Machine Learning.question: Which technique is used to handle imbalanced datasets?
What is the primary purpose of regularization in machine learning?
options: A) To reduce the model complexity
B) To increase the training error
C) To improve the modelâ€™s accuracy
Machine Learning.answer: A) To reduce the model complexity

Machine Learning.question: What does the term 'bagging' refer to in ensemble learning?
options: B) Averaging predictions from multiple models
C) Using decision trees as base models
D) Combining predictions of multiple models
Machine Learning.answer: B) Averaging predictions from multiple models

Machine Learning.question: Which of the following is a dimensionality reduction technique?
Which of the following is NOT a type of machine learning?
What is the primary objective of clustering algorithms?
options: B) To group similar data points together
D) To reduce the size of a dataset
Machine Learning.answer: B) To group similar data points together

Machine Learning.question: In gradient descent, what happens if the learning rate is too small?
options: A) The model may overshoot the optimal solution
B) The model may converge very slowly
C) The model may never converge
Machine Learning.answer: B) The model may converge very slowly

Machine Learning.question: What is the key idea behind a decision tree algorithm?
options: B) To split the dataset into subsets based on features
C) To assign weights to features
D) To cluster data into categories
Machine Learning.answer: B) To split the dataset into subsets based on features

options: A) Adds large values to weights
B) Sets some weights to zero
C) Multiplies weights by a constant
D) Adds random noise to weights
Machine Learning.answer: B) Sets some weights to zero

DistributedSystems.question: What is a distributed system?
options: A) A system where components are located on the same computer
B) A system where components are distributed across different locations
DistributedSystems.answer: B) A system where components are distributed across different locations

DistributedSystems.question: What is the key challenge in distributed systems?
DistributedSystems.answer: B) Data consistency

DistributedSystems.question: In a distributed system, what does the term 'replication' refer to?
options: A) Running the same process multiple times
B) Copying data across multiple nodes
DistributedSystems.answer: B) Copying data across multiple nodes

DistributedSystems.question: Which protocol is commonly used for communication in distributed systems?
DistributedSystems.answer: B) TCP/IP

DistributedSystems.question: What is the CAP theorem in distributed systems?
options: A) Consistency, Availability, and Partition tolerance
B) Capability, Availability, and Processing power
C) Cache, Availability, and Processing power
DistributedSystems.answer: A) Consistency, Availability, and Partition tolerance

DistributedSystems.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of distributed systems?
DistributedSystems.answer: B) Centralization

DistributedSystems.question: What is the purpose of middleware in distributed systems?
options: B) To coordinate communication between distributed components
D) To store data on the cloud
DistributedSystems.answer: B) To coordinate communication between distributed components

DistributedSystems.question: Which of the following is a form of fault tolerance in distributed systems?
DistributedSystems.answer: C) Replication

DistributedSystems.question: What does 'latency' refer to in a distributed system?
options: A) The amount of data transferred per second
B) The delay in communication between nodes
C) The number of nodes in the system
D) The failure rate of components
DistributedSystems.answer: B) The delay in communication between nodes

DistributedSystems.question: Which of the following is an example of a distributed file system?
DistributedSystems.answer: A) HDFS

DistributedSystems.question: What is the role of a 'coordinator' in distributed algorithms like Two-Phase Commit?
DistributedSystems.answer: A) To initiate the communication

DistributedSystems.question: What is 'sharding' in distributed systems?
options: A) Storing the same data in multiple places
B) Splitting data into partitions across multiple databases
C) Creating backup copies of data
DistributedSystems.answer: B) Splitting data into partitions across multiple databases

DistributedSystems.question: What is 'gossip protocol' in distributed systems?
options: A) A protocol for failure detection
B) A protocol for securing communication
C) A protocol for updating nodes about changes
D) A protocol for sharing passwords
DistributedSystems.answer: C) A protocol for updating nodes about changes

DistributedSystems.question: What is 'load balancing' in distributed systems?
options: A) Distributing workload evenly across nodes
DistributedSystems.answer: A) Distributing workload evenly across nodes

DistributedSystems.question: What is a common failure detection mechanism in distributed systems?
DistributedSystems.answer: A) Heartbeat messages

DistributedSystems.question: In distributed computing, what does 'data partitioning' refer to?
options: A) Replicating data on multiple servers
B) Dividing data into smaller segments for processing
C) Encrypting data across different nodes
DistributedSystems.answer: B) Dividing data into smaller segments for processing

DistributedSystems.question: What does 'eventual consistency' mean in a distributed system?
options: A) Data will be consistent immediately after an update
B) Data will eventually become consistent over time
C) There is no guarantee of consistency
D) Data is consistent only during failure
DistributedSystems.answer: B) Data will eventually become consistent over time

DistributedSystems.question: What is 'message passing' in distributed systems?
options: B) Communication between nodes using messages
DistributedSystems.answer: B) Communication between nodes using messages

DistributedSystems.question: Which of the following is a distributed key-value store?
DistributedSystems.answer: A) Redis

DistributedSystems.question: What does 'idempotence' mean in distributed systems?
options: B) The ability to perform the same operation multiple times without changing the result
C) The process of managing node failures
DistributedSystems.answer: B) The ability to perform the same operation multiple times without changing the result

DistributedSystems.question: What is the primary goal of fault-tolerant distributed systems?
DistributedSystems.answer: B) Reliability

DistributedSystems.question: In a distributed system, what does 'consensus' mean?
options: A) Agreement between nodes on a shared state
DistributedSystems.answer: A) Agreement between nodes on a shared state

DistributedSystems.question: What is the key feature of a 'peer-to-peer' distributed system?
options: B) Nodes function as both clients and servers
DistributedSystems.answer: B) Nodes function as both clients and servers

DistributedSystems.question: What does the term 'scalability' refer to in distributed systems?
options: A) The ability to handle a growing amount of work
B) The ability to reduce the number of nodes
C) The ability to shut down nodes
D) The ability to balance resources
DistributedSystems.answer: A) The ability to handle a growing amount of work

DistributedSystems.question: Which of the following is an example of a distributed database system?
DistributedSystems.answer: A) Cassandra

System Design.question: What is horizontal scaling?
options: A) Adding more CPUs to an existing machine
B) Adding more machines to handle load
System Design.answer: B) Adding more machines to handle load

System Design.question: What does CAP theorem stand for?
System Design.answer: A) Consistency, Availability, Partition Tolerance

System Design.question: What is a load balancer?
options: A) A tool to manage memory
B) A system to distribute incoming traffic
C) A system to cache data
D) A tool to handle backups
System Design.answer: B) A system to distribute incoming traffic

System Design.question: Which of the following is NOT a distributed database?
System Design.answer: C) MySQL

System Design.question: What is the purpose of caching in a system?
System Design.answer: B) To reduce database load

System Design.question: What is the primary role of an API gateway in microservices architecture?
System Design.answer: D) Request routing

System Design.question: What is the best way to handle sudden traffic spikes?
System Design.answer: C) Horizontal scaling

System Design.question: What does 'fault tolerance' in system design refer to?
options: A) System's ability to handle failures
B) System's ability to recover data
System Design.answer: A) System's ability to handle failures

System Design.question: What is a CDN (Content Delivery Network) used for?
options: B) Cache content closer to users
System Design.answer: B) Cache content closer to users

System Design.question: In a distributed system, what is 'replication'?
System Design.answer: B) Duplicating data across servers

System Design.question: What is a 'message queue' used for in a system?
System Design.answer: A) For asynchronous communication

System Design.question: What is a monolithic architecture?
options: A) A system where all components are tightly integrated
D) A system with many layers
System Design.answer: A) A system where all components are tightly integrated

System Design.question: Which type of database is best suited for large-scale, distributed systems?
System Design.answer: A) NoSQL

System Design.question: What is a 'heartbeat' signal used for in system design?
options: B) To check if nodes are alive
System Design.answer: B) To check if nodes are alive

System Design.question: What is the best design approach for read-heavy systems?
System Design.answer: B) Implement caching

System Design.question: What is 'autoscaling' in system design?
options: A) Manually adjusting the number of servers
B) Automatically increasing or decreasing resources based on load
D) Reducing the number of services in a system
System Design.answer: B) Automatically increasing or decreasing resources based on load

System Design.question: Which of the following is NOT a principle of microservices architecture?
options: B) Single database for all services
D) Services communication over lightweight protocols
System Design.answer: B) Single database for all services

System Design.question: What is 'sharding' in system design?
options: A) Encrypting data across different nodes
B) Splitting data across multiple databases
C) Creating backup copies of data
D) Storing the same data in multiple places
System Design.answer: B) Splitting data across multiple databases

System Design.question: What is 'latency' in system design?
options: A) Amount of data transferred per second
B) Delay between request and response
C) Number of nodes in the system
System Design.answer: B) Delay between request and response

System Design.question: What is 'eventual consistency'?
options: A) Data is always consistent across systems
B) Data will eventually become consistent over time
D) Data is consistent only during failures
System Design.answer: B) Data will eventually become consistent over time

System Design.question: In a distributed system, what is 'gossip protocol'?
options: B) For failure detection and spreading information
System Design.answer: B) For failure detection and spreading information

System Design.question: What is a key principle in RESTful system design?
System Design.answer: B) Stateless interactions

System Design.question: What is 'write amplification'?
options: A) Writing large amounts of data in one operation
B) A phenomenon where more writes are performed than necessary
C) Reducing write operations to save bandwidth
D) A mechanism for faster writes
System Design.answer: B) A phenomenon where more writes are performed than necessary

System Design.question: What is a 'rate limiter'?
options: A) A system that limits the amount of data stored
B) A system that limits the number of requests a client can make
C) A tool for speeding up processing
D) A mechanism to cache requests
System Design.answer: B) A system that limits the number of requests a client can make

System Design.question: What is the role of a 'scheduler' in a distributed system?
options: A) To distribute tasks across multiple nodes
B) To execute processes in a sequence
System Design.answer: A) To distribute tasks across multiple nodes

options: A) Methods with the same name but different return types
B) Methods with the same name but different parameters
C) Methods with different names but same functionality
D) Using multiple methods within a class
Java.answer: B) Methods with the same name but different parameters

options: A) The method can only be called from within the same class
B) The method or variable belongs to the class, not an instance
C) The method cannot be changed
Java.answer: B) The method or variable belongs to the class, not an instance

options: A) To prevent modification of variables, methods, or classes

Java.question: In which part of memory are objects stored?
What does the 'new' keyword do in Java?
options: A) Allocates memory for a new object

Java.question: What is the purpose of encapsulation in Java?
options: A) To hide the internal details of an object
Java.answer: A) To hide the internal details of an object

Databases.question: Which of the following is a type of database model?
What is SQL used for in databases?
Which of the following is a primary key?
options: A) A unique identifier for a record in a table
C) A duplicate field in a table
D) A key used for indexing
Databases.answer: A) A unique identifier for a record in a table

Databases.question: What is a foreign key in relational databases?
options: A) A key that links two tables together
B) A key that enforces data integrity
C) A key that is unique in the table
D) A key that can store duplicate values
Databases.answer: A) A key that links two tables together

Databases.question: Which of the following SQL commands is used to retrieve data from a database?
What does the acronym ACID stand for in database transactions?
What is normalization in databases?
options: A) The process of organizing data to avoid redundancy
B) A method of indexing data
C) The process of backing up data
D) A method of encrypting data
Databases.answer: A) The process of organizing data to avoid redundancy

Databases.question: In which normal form is a table when it has no repeating groups or arrays?
Which of the following SQL clauses is used to filter records?
What is the purpose of the JOIN operation in SQL?
options: A) To retrieve data from multiple tables based on a related column
B) To delete records from multiple tables
C) To modify multiple columns simultaneously
D) To group records based on similar values
Databases.answer: A) To retrieve data from multiple tables based on a related column

Databases.question: Which type of join returns all rows from the left table and matching rows from the right table?
What is the result of an INNER JOIN if no match is found in the joined tables?
options: A) Null values in unmatched rows
B) Only matched rows are returned
C) All rows from both tables are returned
Databases.answer: B) Only matched rows are returned

Databases.question: Which SQL keyword is used to eliminate duplicate rows in the result set?
Which of the following is true for a clustered index?
options: A) It defines the physical order of data in a table
B) It is used for non-unique records only
C) It always has unique values
D) It cannot be used with primary keys
Databases.answer: A) It defines the physical order of data in a table

Databases.question: What is a view in a database?
options: A) A virtual table based on the result of an SQL query
B) A physical table stored in the database
C) A tool used for data backup
D) A method of encrypting tables
Databases.answer: A) A virtual table based on the result of an SQL query

Databases.question: Which SQL statement is used to create a new table?
Which SQL keyword is used to update existing data in a table?
Which function is used to count the number of records in an SQL query?
What is the function of a trigger in a database?
options: A) To automatically execute a stored procedure in response to certain events
Databases.answer: A) To automatically execute a stored procedure in response to certain events

Databases.question: Which of the following is an aggregate function in SQL?
What is a stored procedure in a database?
options: A) A precompiled collection of SQL statements
B) A temporary table stored in memory
D) A physical view of the database schema
Databases.answer: A) A precompiled collection of SQL statements

Databases.question: Which database index improves the performance of queries?
What does the term 'referential integrity' refer to in a database?
options: A) Ensuring that foreign key values match primary key values in related tables
B) Storing only unique values in a table
C) Using indexed columns in a query
Databases.answer: A) Ensuring that foreign key values match primary key values in related tables

Databases.question: What is the purpose of the ROLLBACK statement in SQL?
options: A) To undo changes made by a transaction
B) To commit changes made by a transaction
C) To lock a table during a transaction
D) To create a new database
Databases.answer: A) To undo changes made by a transaction

Databases.question: What is the main advantage of indexing a database?

Object-Oriented Programming.question: Which of the following best describes inheritance?
options: A) A mechanism for sharing code between unrelated classes
B) A way to hide data
C) A way to create new classes based on existing ones
D) A method for encapsulating functions
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: C) A way to create new classes based on existing ones

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What is encapsulation in OOP?
options: A) The process of extending classes
B) The bundling of data with methods that operate on that data
C) The ability to treat objects of different classes the same way
D) The practice of sharing code between classes
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: B) The bundling of data with methods that operate on that data

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What does polymorphism allow in OOP?
options: A) The ability to create multiple instances of a class
B) The ability to call the same method on different objects
C) The ability to inherit multiple classes
D) The ability to hide implementation details
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: B) The ability to call the same method on different objects

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What keyword is used to inherit a class in Java?
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: C) extends

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What is method overriding?
options: A) Creating a new method in a derived class with the same name and parameters as a method in the base class
B) Creating multiple methods with the same name but different parameters
C) Hiding a method from a base class
D) Defining a method that cannot be called
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: A) Creating a new method in a derived class with the same name and parameters as a method in the base class

Object-Oriented Programming.question: In which of the following scenarios would you use an abstract class?
options: A) When you want to create a class that can be instantiated
B) When you want to define common behavior for derived classes without providing a complete implementation
C) When you want to create a utility class
D) When you want to implement an interface
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: B) When you want to define common behavior for derived classes without providing a complete implementation

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What is the primary benefit of using interfaces in OOP?
options: C) They can contain method definitions with bodies
D) They can be used to achieve polymorphism
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: D) They can be used to achieve polymorphism

Object-Oriented Programming.question: Which of the following statements about constructors is true?
options: A) They can have a return type
B) They are called when an object is destroyed
D) They are called explicitly by the user
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: C) They can be overloaded

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What is the purpose of the super keyword in Java?
options: A) To call a method from a parent class
B) To access the current object's methods
C) To create a new instance of a class
D) To invoke a static method
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: A) To call a method from a parent class

Object-Oriented Programming.question: Which of the following is true about static variables?
options: A) They are unique to each instance of a class
B) They can be accessed without creating an object of the class
C) They can be overridden in derived classes
D) They are only accessible within the class they are declared in
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: B) They can be accessed without creating an object of the class

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What does the term 'constructor chaining' refer to?
options: A) Calling one constructor from another constructor within the same class
B) Creating multiple instances of a class
C) Inheriting constructors from a base class
D) Calling multiple methods in succession
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: A) Calling one constructor from another constructor within the same class

Object-Oriented Programming.question: Which of the following is NOT a principle of OOP?
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: D) Compilation

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What is the function of the final keyword in the context of a class?
options: A) It allows the class to be subclassed
B) It prevents the class from being subclassed
C) It restricts access to the class
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: B) It prevents the class from being subclassed

Object-Oriented Programming.question: Which of the following describes a concrete class?
options: A) A class that contains only abstract methods
B) A class that can be instantiated
C) A class with no methods
D) A class that only serves as a base class
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: B) A class that can be instantiated

Object-Oriented Programming.question: In OOP, what is the purpose of an interface?
options: B) To define a set of methods that implementing classes must provide
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: B) To define a set of methods that implementing classes must provide

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What does the abstract keyword signify in OOP?
options: A) That a class cannot be inherited
B) That a class can be instantiated
C) That a method must be implemented in derived classes
D) That a method cannot be overridden
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: C) That a method must be implemented in derived classes

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What is the difference between 'is-a' and 'has-a' relationships in OOP?
options: A) 'Is-a' indicates inheritance, while 'has-a' indicates composition
B) 'Is-a' is used for methods, while 'has-a' is used for properties
D) 'Is-a' refers to data hiding, while 'has-a' refers to encapsulation
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: A) 'Is-a' indicates inheritance, while 'has-a' indicates composition

Object-Oriented Programming.question: Which of the following allows a class to inherit properties and behaviors from multiple classes?
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: C) Multiple inheritance

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What is the role of the this keyword in OOP?
options: A) To refer to the parent class
B) To refer to the current instance of the class
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: B) To refer to the current instance of the class

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What is an example of a 'has-a' relationship?
options: A) A Dog is an Animal
B) A Car has an Engine
C) A Teacher is a Person
D) A Cat is an Animal
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: B) A Car has an Engine

Object-Oriented Programming.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of an object?
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: D) Syntax

Object-Oriented Programming.question: What does the @Override annotation do in Java?
options: A) It indicates that a method cannot be overridden
B) It indicates that a method is being overridden from a superclass
D) It defines an abstract class
Object-Oriented Programming.answer: B) It indicates that a method is being overridden from a superclass

Agile Methodologies.answer: B) Scrum

Agile Methodologies.question: What is the purpose of a sprint in Scrum?
options: B) To deliver a potentially shippable product increment
Agile Methodologies.answer: B) To deliver a potentially shippable product increment

Agile Methodologies.question: In Agile, what is a user story?

Agile Methodologies.answer: B) A feature written from the perspective of an end-user

Agile Methodologies.question: What is the role of a Scrum Master?

D) To prioritize the product backlog
Agile Methodologies.answer: B) To ensure the team follows Agile practices and removes impediments

Agile Methodologies.question: Which of the following is a key principle of Agile?

D) Processes and tools are more important than people
Agile Methodologies.answer: B) Prioritizing customer satisfaction through early and continuous delivery

Agile Methodologies.question: What does the term 'burndown chart' refer to in Agile?

B) A chart showing remaining work over time
C) A list of user stories
Agile Methodologies.answer: B) A chart showing remaining work over time

Agile Methodologies.question: In Agile, what is a retrospective?

D) A meeting to update documentation
Agile Methodologies.answer: B) A review of completed work and lessons learned

Agile Methodologies.question: Which of the following is a common Agile practice?

Agile Methodologies.question: What is the main goal of continuous integration in Agile?

Agile Methodologies.answer: C) To frequently integrate code changes into a shared repository

Agile Methodologies.question: In Agile, what is the significance of 'working software'?

B) It is more valuable than comprehensive documentation

Agile Methodologies.answer: B) It is more valuable than comprehensive documentation

Agile Methodologies.question: Which Agile framework emphasizes delivering work in small, incremental pieces?

Agile Methodologies.question: What is the purpose of a product backlog in Agile?

B) To prioritize and manage features, enhancements, and fixes
Agile Methodologies.answer: B) To prioritize and manage features, enhancements, and fixes

Agile Methodologies.question: What does 'velocity' measure in Agile?
options: B) The amount of work completed in a sprint
C) The time taken to complete a project
Agile Methodologies.answer: B) The amount of work completed in a sprint

Agile Methodologies.question: In Agile, what is a 'definition of done'?
options: B) A set of criteria that a product increment must meet to be considered complete
C) A document outlining project goals
D) A timeline for project completion
Agile Methodologies.answer: B) A set of criteria that a product increment must meet to be considered complete

Agile Methodologies.question: Which of the following best describes the term 'increment' in Agile?
options: A) A partial release of the project
B) A complete and functional addition to the product
C) An update to project documentation
Agile Methodologies.answer: B) A complete and functional addition to the product

Agile Methodologies.question: What is a Kanban board used for in Agile?

Agile Methodologies.answer: B) To visualize work in progress and manage flow

Agile Methodologies.question: In Agile, what is the role of the product owner?
options: A) To manage the development team

Agile Methodologies.answer: B) To represent the stakeholders and prioritize the product backlog

Agile Methodologies.question: Which of the following is not a characteristic of Agile development?
Agile Methodologies.answer: C) Fixed project requirements

Agile Methodologies.answer: B) Two developers working together at one workstation

Agile Methodologies.question: What is the primary focus of a Scrum team?

Agile Methodologies.answer: B) To produce a potentially shippable product increment every sprint

Agile Methodologies.question: In Agile, what is meant by 'adaptive planning'?
options: B) Adjusting plans based on changing requirements and feedback
Agile Methodologies.answer: B) Adjusting plans based on changing requirements and feedback

Agile Methodologies.question: Which of the following roles is not part of a Scrum team?
Agile Methodologies.answer: D) Project Manager

Agile Methodologies.question: What is the significance of 'customer collaboration' in Agile?

Agile Methodologies.answer: C) It helps ensure the product meets customer needs

Agile Methodologies.question: What is a 'release plan' in Agile?

Agile Methodologies.answer: B) A plan for delivering product increments to users
